title: ‘Nothing to See Here’ except kids on fire in Kevin Wilson’s bizarre, fun new novel
text:
CLOSE

"Nothing to See Here," by Kevin Wilson. (Photo: Ecco)

“Nothing to See Here” (Ecco, 254 pages, ★★★½ out of four stars) starts out normal enough. Lillian is 28 years old, working dead-end cashier jobs, smoking too much weed and living in her mom’s attic when her best friend from high school, Madison, reaches out. She’s rich and beautiful and married to a powerful senator now. Lillian is maybe in love with her.

Madison needs Lillian to do her a solid – paid, of course. The senator’s two kids from a previous marriage are coming to live at their Tennessee estate. They’re a bit of a handful, and Madison wants Lillian’s help caring for them and getting them acclimated. It’s a big job, but what else is Lillian doing? Sure, she’ll come play governess at Madison’s mansion. She’s got nothing going. What the heck?

There’s just one catch: The children catch fire. Literally. As in, they spontaneously combust.

More: Prince memoir 'The Beautiful Ones' offers a glimpse inside the mind of a musical genius

It’s a giddily lunatic premise, one that author Kevin Wilson (“The Family Fang”) grounds with humor and deadpan matter-of-factness. Told in Lillian’s refreshingly unfiltered and a-touch-crude voice, the story makes a pair of spontaneously combusting children seem plausible. “This is weird, Madison,” Lillian says when her friend makes her pitch. “You want me to raise your husband’s fire children.”

Bessie and Roland's episodes are triggered by emotion or stress, like panic attacks, and there's a lot of emotion and stress that comes with being an unwanted fire child. They don’t die when they combust, just smolder for a bit, destroying any clothing or combustibles in their path. Their mother, who raised them without the senator’s help, died by suicide, ostensibly from the stress of raising them. The children are pariahs, their condition a liability to their father’s political ambitions and a physical danger to his son with Madison, Timothy.

Lillian is a bit of a pariah too, though she oughtn’t be. As a teen, she was kicked out of the posh prep school she shared with Madison; Madison was there because she was rich, Lillian because she was smart. When Madison was caught with drugs, Lillian was urged to take the fall. Now one of them is married to the potential future secretary of state, and the other mans a cash register.

Author Kevin Wilson. (Photo: Leigh Anne Couch)

Wilson’s observational humor is riotous in its specificity, his descriptions as generous as fistfuls of Halloween candy at the best house on the block. When we meet the senator, he’s “wearing a linen suit, looking like a preacher about to say the Lord’s Prayer before the start of the Daytona 500.” Even when Lillian first sees Bessie catch fire, the writing dazzles as much as the girl. “And then, like a crack of lightning, she burst fully into flames, her body a kind of firework, the fire white and blue and red all at once. It was beautiful, no lie, to watch a person burn.”

But what dazzles most are the warmly rendered dynamics of an ad hoc, dysfunctional family that desperately wants to work. Lillian, Bessie and Roland make for a shabby and ramshackle trio. But the more time Lillian spends with the kids, the more of herself she sees in the combative little human sparklers, the more driven she is to turn their liability into an asset. How do you learn to celebrate rather than mask what sets you apart, even if that thing is spontaneous human combustion?

Yes, Bessie and Roland are weird and broken. So is Lillian. So are, when you really start digging, picture-perfect Madison, her senator husband and cute little Timothy.

So is everyone.
